name: electricity production, hard coal, conventional | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2016.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is representative of the coal fired power plants in operation in South Africa in 2016.It thus represents the older conventional power plants, with the supercritical power plants currently under construction represented in "electricity production, hard coal, supercritical, ZA".
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is representative of the coal-fired power plants currently in operation in South Africa. These are conventional pulverised fuel boilers employing a mix of either wet or dry cooling, wet or dry ashing and electrostatic precipitators or fabric filters. The stations do not have flue gas desulphurisation (FGD) or selective catalytic reduction (SCR) for NOx removal.The stations range in age from 19 to 54 years, and are each comprised of 6 to 10 units, with the units ranging in installed capacity from 90 to 713 MW each. This dataset is representative of Eskom's installed capacity of 38,548 MW, which accounts for approximately 98.5% of South Africa's coal-fired electricity.;Overall thermal efficiency is 31%, with the average coal burnt of low quality: 28.6% ash and calorific value of 20 MJ/kg;No flue gas desulphurisation is installed (coal is low sulphur, at 0.84% sulphur on a dry basis).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Emissions to air other than CO2, N2O, NOx, SOx, particulates and Hg are taken from the existing ecoivent dataset, where the following comments apply: 

Data from 1993 were updated for the years 2000 (v1.0), and 2004-2005 (v2.0). Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly. 

Most of the exchanges were extrapolated through production-weighted averages of the datasets of the following 14 countries: AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US.

The original data were valid for the burning of 1MJ of hard coal. In this dataset, the values are scaled to the net output of 1kWh of electricity, based on the electrical efficiency.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Technical statistics published annually by Eskom in their Integrated report is used to provide data on coal quality, electrical efficiency, coal consumption, water consumption, ash volumes, and emissions of carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide and particulates. Individual power station data was used where Eskom-wide figures were not available (fuel oil and boiler water makeup). Mercury emissions are taken from the literature (Garnham and Langeman, 2016). Power station infrastructure and all other emissions to air are taken from the existing electricity production from hard coal dataset in ecoinvent (see extrapolation comment). Sources: Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pdf; Garnham, B and Langeman, K (2016) Mercury emissions from South Africa’s coal-fired power stations, Clean Air Journal, Vol. 26, No2, 2016. Available at: http://www.cleanairjournal.org.za/download/caj_vol26_no2_2016_p14.pdf

exchanges.description: This is power sent out from power station, i.e. net power generated after allowing for own use

exchanges.description:
Value not specific to South Africa. Generic value from previous ecoinvent dataset, with original comment as follows:  Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from hard coal, based on the value for burning 1MJ of hard coal. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and emission values of 14 countries 
(AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US) (Röder et al. 2007) 
Country emissions values calculated from trace element balance, input uncertain

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

flow.name: Nitrogen oxides
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Eskom's power stations range from nominal 200 MW units to 600 MW units, however 80% of the power is generated from eight 6 x 600 MW power stations. The overall generation load factor in 2016 was 57.9%. The nominal plant life is 30 years, although eight of the thirteen currently operating power station are older than 30 years (with the oldest at 52 years).

flow.name: Radium-226
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Mercury emissions from Eskom's coal-fired power stations from a study by Garnham and Langeman (2016). Calculated value based on the amount of coal burnt per annum per power station, the mercury content (ppm) of the coal used at each power and technology-specific mercury emission reduction factors sourced from the US EPA (2013) and UNEP (2015). Overall approach is that of ‘Toolkit for Identification and Quantification of Mercury Releases’ (UNEP 2015).  

Source: 
Garnham, B and Langeman, K (2016) Mercury emissions from South Africa’s coal-fired power stations, Clean Air Journal, Vol. 26, No2, 2016. Available at: http://www.cleanairjournal.org.za/download/caj_vol26_no2_2016_p14.pdf

flow.name: Cyanide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Total particulate emissions reported by Eskom (10-year technical statistics). The figure reported by Eskom is a calculated figure based on power station design parameters, coal characteristics and coal tonnages burnt. Eskom reports total particulates only, so the size distribution is taken from the existing ecoinvent dataset for electricity production from hard coal, i.e. 25% of the particulate emissions are < 2.5um, 72% are > 10 um and 3% are between 2.5 um and 10 um. Source: Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pdf

flow.name: Arsenic ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: All water loss assumed to be evaporative, i.e. water to air = boiler water makeup + cooling water makeup. All water use at the power stations is consumptive, i.e. there are no return flows to rivers. In the power station water plants, water use is optimised through cascading water quality cycles (e.g. boiler blowdown goes into the cooling water clarifiers). Water of the lowest quality is used for ash quenching and ash slurrying (wet ashing stations only). Any remaining water of too poor quality to be used is stored in dams on site. All water loss is therefore assumed to be evaporative, i.e. cooling towers in wet cooled stations, steam leaks and evaporation from ash dams and storage ponds. Potential seepage losses from ash dams and storage ponds are not accounted for due to a lack of data, neither are occasional spills from storage dams in high rainfall events.

flow.name: Ethyl benzene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Total nitrous oxide emissions reported by Eskom (10-year technical statistics). The figure reported by Eskom is a calculated figure based on power station design parameters, coal characteristics and coal tonnages burnt, and includes coal-fired and gas turbine power stations (burning diesel), as well as oil consumed during power station start-ups. The Eskom figure has been adjusted using the IPCC default N2O emission factor for Gas/Diesel oil combustion in energy industries and the quantity of diesel burnt by Eskom to deduct the N2O emissions from the OCGT power stations.  

Source: 
Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pd

flow.name: Benzene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Total carbon dioxide emissions reported by Eskom (10-year technical statistics). The figure reported by Eskom is a calculated figure based on power station design parameters, coal analysis and coal tonnages burnt, and includes coal-fired and gas turbine power stations (burning diesel) and the underground coal gasification pilot plant, as well as oil consumed during power station start-ups. The Eskom figure has been adjusted using the IPCC default CO2 emission factor for Gas/Diesel oil combustion in energy industries and the quantity of diesel burnt by Eskom to deduct the CO2 emissions from the OCGT power stations (the figure has not been adjusted for the UCG pilot plant but as the output of this is extremely small the effect is negligible). 

Source: 
Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pdf

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Eskom report only an overall specific raw water consumption, which in 2016, was 1.39 litres per kilowatt-hour sent out (Eskom, 2017). This raw water use includes both water required for cooling purposes and ultrapure water for use in the boilers. Detailed water balance data from three power stations was used to estimate an average boiler water requirement of 0.03 litres per kilowatt-hour sent out (2.2% of total raw water use at the power stations). Source: Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pdf

flow.name: Acrolein
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Total particulate emissions reported by Eskom (10-year technical statistics). The figure reported by Eskom is a calculated figure based on power station design parameters, coal characteristics and coal tonnages burnt. Eskom reports total particulates only, so the size distribution is taken from the existing ecoinvent dataset for electricity production from hard coal, i.e. 25% of the particulate emissions are < 2.5um, 72% are > 10 um and 3% are between 2.5 um and 10 um. Source: Eskom Integrated Report 31 March 2017, Available at: http://www.eskom.co.za/IR2017/Documents/Eskom_integrated_report_2017.pdf
